Yes, there have been several success stories in using machine learning in ICUs. Here are a few examples:

1. Early Detection of Sepsis: A study published in the Journal of Intensive Care Medicine showed that a machine learning algorithm could predict sepsis up to 12 hours before clinical recognition with 76% accuracy.

2. Predicting Readmissions: A Cleveland Clinic study found that a machine learning model could predict readmissions within 30 days of a hospital discharge with 82% accuracy, enabling clinicians to intervene early and prevent costly and avoidable hospital readmissions.

3. Optimizing Insulin Therapy: A machine learning algorithm was used to optimize insulin therapy for critically ill patients in a study published in the Journal of Diabetes Science and Technology. The algorithm was successful in keeping blood sugar levels within the target range for a higher percentage of the time than standard insulin therapy.

4. Personalized Care Plans: The University of Pittsburgh Medical Center (UPMC) has developed a machine learning system that generates real-time personalized care plans for patients in the ICU based on their individual medical histories, vital signs, and lab results. This has resulted in better outcomes and reduced ICU stays.

These success stories demonstrate the potential of machine learning in improving patient outcomes and reducing healthcare costs in ICUs.
